contents.markdown: About plain pseudo-verbs: although I listed seven words above, we will not use _maaari_ because it means the same as _puwede_ but is less common. We will not use _dapat_ because it is similar in meaning to _ng_ pseudo-verb _kailangan_ but less common. _Meron_ has already been covered. We used _mahilig_ to like a noun in general. But it is not a pseudo-verb, and it is more common to use ng pseudo-verb _gusto_ to like a verb, so we do not cover _mahilig_+ verb. That leaves us with _bawal_, _puwede_ and _huwag_.
Plain pseudo verb Sentence. = **Plain pseudo-verb** (+ linker) + SS.
**Notes: Verb takes infinitive. The linker goes before the verb. Use the linker if it is -_ng_ type, but omit it if it is _na_.**
To form these, take all the enclitics out of the standard sentence and put them after the pseudo-verb, then change the verb to infinitive.

item.english: Can you play? Notice that the AF actor keeps its ang form. That is why these are called plain pseudo-verbs.
Can David play? Notice that, unlike ng pseudo-verbs, the non personal pronoun AF actor is not moved.

contents.markdown: If you just want to express ability, remember that you do not need to use _puwede_ with verbs that have the nuance of ability, like certain _ma_- verbs:

item.english: I will be able to get the bicycle.
I can get the bicycle, but it sounds redundant because makuha already has the meaning to be able to get. Compare with:
I can get the bicycle, without sounding redundant.
You are prohibited from looking for Maria.

item.tagalog: Huwag mo siyang igawa ng adobo.
item.english: Do not make her adobo.

contents.markdown: Although _huwag_ is used in some more advanced constructions, we only use it to negate imperative sentences in this book.

item.tagalog: Huwag kayong magluto ng pagkain ngayon.
item.english: (you pl) Do not cook food now.
Let’s not look at the bicycle.

item.tagalog: Huwag mong ikuha ng mangga si Joe.
item.english: Do not get a mango for Joe.

contents.markdown: <u>Huwag behaves like a host for Ito and Yun</u>
Colloquially, in _huwag_ phrases, similar to _hindi_, demonstrative pronouns _ito_ and _yun_ are normally placed at the end of the enclitic cluster by native speakers.

item.english: (you pl) Do not cook it now.
Let’s not look at that.

item.tagalog: Huwag mo itong ikuha ng mangga.
item.english: Do not get a mango for it.

contents.markdown: Like ng pseudo-verbs, in general plain pseudo-verbs are negated with _hindi_. But _bawal_ is already a negation of _puwede_(may), and _huwag_ negates imperative sentences, so they do not take _hindi_. _Hindi puwede_ will mean “unable” in this book. It can also mean “may not” colloquially, but we will only use _bawal_ for that to be consistent.

item.tagalog: Bawal mo ring hanapin si Maria.
item.english: You are also prohibited from looking for Maria.
Do not play basketball.
The tree cannot become big.

contents.markdown: _Ng_ and plain pseudo-verb non-AF sentences, and plain pseudo-verb AF sentences, use the same grammar. _Ng_ pseudo-verb AF sentences are different. Unlike the others, in _ng_ pseudo-verb AF sentences:
It is mandatory to change the actor to _ng_ form.
It is preferred to put the actor after the pseudo-verb even when it is not a personal pronoun.

item.english: Joe does not want to go.

item.tagalog: Plain: Puwede bang pumunta si Joe?
item.english: Can Joe go?

item.tagalog: Ng: Kailangan ninyong inumin ang tubig na yun.
item.english: You (pl) need to drink that water.

item.tagalog: Plain: Huwag ninyong inumin ang tubig na yun.
item.english: (you pl) Do not drink that water.

item.tagalog: Ng: Gusto rin po ni David na magbigay ng sasakyan sa kanila.
item.english: David also wants to give them a car. (resp.)

item.tagalog: Plain: Bawal din pong magbigay si David ng sasakyan sa kanila.
item.english: David is also prohibited from giving them a car. (resp.)

exampleSentences.tagalog: Bawal kang gumawa ng halo-halo sa tabi ng mga manok, no?
exampleSentences.english: You are prohibited from making halo-halo next to the chickens, right?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Puwede ko bang kainin ang tsokolate sa ilalim ng lamesa?
exampleSentences.english: May I eat the chocolate under the table?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Huwag kayong umalis sa ikaapat ng Hulyo.
exampleSentences.english: Do not (you pl.) leave on the 4th of July.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Puwede mo siyang makita kapag nandito ka.
exampleSentences.english: You are allowed to see her when you are here.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Hindi kami puwedeng umuwi sa Luzon sa Oktubre para sa iyo.
exampleSentences.english: We (excl.) are unable to go home to Luzon in October for you.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Bawal mapunta si Mark sa kuwarto ni Jessica.
exampleSentences.english: Mark is prohibited from winding up in Jessica's room.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Huwag mo akong ibili ng tubig kapag nasa tindahan ka.
exampleSentences.english: Do not buy me water when you are in the store.
She is not allowed to sleep outside.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Hindi rin po ba puwedeng igawa ni Maria ng sapatos si Angel?
exampleSentences.english: Isn't Maria also able to make shoes for Angel? (resp.)
